image.altText: A man leans an arm against a bar top, behind him bottles of alcohol and a neon bar sign

props.synopsis: For decades, a mainstay of the live music scene was the adolescent "rite of passage" of going out to gigs, concerts and band nights in the back rooms of pubs — but Adelaide industry figures say factors including TikTok and the after-effects of the pandemic are continuing to keep young people away.

title.children: The peak of the pandemic has long since passed — but live music is still struggling to make itself heard

image.altText: A graphic shows a man and a woman against a black background adorned with Indigenous art.

props.synopsis: Black excellence and community leadership were honoured at the 2024 National NAIDOC Week Awards in Tarndanya (Adelaide) on Kaurna Yerta Country on Saturday evening.

title.children: National NAIDOC Week Awards 2024: Here are all of this year's finalists and winners

image.altText: Angie King marries Eric Burdon

props.synopsis: Jet James was eight when his mother died tragically. His journey back from childhood trauma led him in an unexpected direction.

title.children: Jet's mother was a sixties model who married rock royalty but her life met a tragic end

image.altText: A woman entering a red, white and blue voting booth

props.synopsis: Left-wing and centrist parties in France have joined forces in a bid to prevent the far-right winning a majority of seats in parliament in this weekend's final round of voting. Here's your guide.

title.children: Political rivals in France are banding together to block the far right. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: Chrstine Cloud sits on a sofa. She is speaking.

props.synopsis: Christine Cloud never thought she'd be forced to move in with her father in retirement, but the rising cost of living is biting in Nevada. Now, she's an example of Joe Biden's big problem in the crucial swing state.

title.children: This Vegas voter is backing the 'scary' candidate. She's an example of Biden's problem in America's gambling capital

image.altText: Fraser Ellis outside court

props.synopsis: After Fraser Ellis was found guilty this week of four counts of deception over his misuse of the Country Members Accommodation Allowance, the question over his political future remains unclear, Harvey Biggs explains.

title.children: Why $238 could cost a South Australian independent MP his seat

image.altText: The entrance to the new visitor centre on Kangaroo Island

props.synopsis: One of the final pieces of the rebuild following the Kangaroo Island bushfires has slotted into place, with the opening of a new tourist centre at Flinders Chase National Park.

title.children: New Kangaroo Island visitor centre rises from the ashes

image.altText: President Joe Biden announced a foreign aid package

props.synopsis: Joe Biden says he will only drop out of the US presidential race if the Lord Almighty himself tells him to after a shaky debate performance raised questions about his suitability.

title.children: A defiant Joe Biden appears in denial — will his television interview save his candidacy?

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed with a serious look on his face with th Hard quiz logo in the top left corner

props.synopsis: So you think you're some kind of master of general knowledge? Well, I'll be the judge of that.

title.children: It's time to flex your trivia muscle. Have you got what it takes?

image.altText: Mailbox outside a derelict terrace house

props.synopsis: As Australians endure the latest acute phase of a decades-long housing crisis, why are property owners allowed to leave homes derelict and prime land vacant indefinitely?

title.children: A person's home may be their castle but if they leave it vacant can they really complain if it gets taken away?

image.altText: Vicky Xu poses for a photo sitting on concrete steps outside.

props.synopsis: An Australian citizen, identified as a potential target of suspected foreign interference, says the AFP cut official contact with her after she complained about an alleged assault by their officers and criticised the agency in a post on X.

title.children: 'You guys suck': Target of suspected foreign interference campaign says AFP cut off contact after complaint and tweet

image.altText: Margaret Campbell dressed in a fur coat clutches a purse standing next to a man dressed in a suit with a bowtie.

props.synopsis: The duke and duchess of Argyll's 20th-century divorce proceedings saw a wife slut-shamed, exiled from high society and turned into one of the earliest, most famous victims of revenge porn. Here's how the case unfolded.

title.children: Revenge porn, a crumbling castle, and the scandalous divorce that rocked British high society

image.altText: A girl lights earthen lamps in the shape of a red ribbon.

props.synopsis: The Philippines has seen a 411 per cent increase in daily HIV cases in a little over a decade. Experts blame conservatism and shame.

title.children: 'Tip of the iceberg': Why HIV cases in this country have skyrocketed over the past decade

image.altText: Rubble lies across a damaged green car as crowds inspect the scene of an air strike

props.synopsis: At least 16 people are dead after an Israeli strike on a school sheltering displaced Palestinian families in central Gaza, the Palestinian health ministry says.

title.children: Gaza school hit in deadly Israeli strike as ceasefire talks continue

image.altText: A close up photo of Caroline Jones, smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: Long-running Australian Story presenter Caroline Jones bequeathed $1.7m towards Indigenous high school education in her final gift to the community.

title.children: Founding Australian Story presenter Caroline Jones's $1.7m gift

image.altText: A young child gets there nose blown.

props.synopsis: Children attending childcare get sick more often than those who don't, according to research. But is there light at the end of the tunnel for parents? Here's what we know about Childcare illnesses, and how you can prevent your kids from getting worse this Winter.

title.children: Why does my child get sick so often? The snotty statistics behind childcare illnesses

image.altText: Jesse Hogan celebrates a goal passionately

props.synopsis: GWS puts a dent in Carlton's run of form with a stirring come-from-behind victory, while Fremantle moves up to third on the AFL ladder with a professional 51-point win over Richmond.

title.children: Giants bring Blues back down to earth with scintilating comeback win, Dockers lock down top four spot

image.altText: Bags of plasma

props.synopsis: Australia imported hundreds of millions of dollars in plasma products from overseas last year to make up a national shortfall.

title.children: As Australia's reliance on imported blood plasma grows, the ethics of paid donation are back in focus

image.altText: A young man and an older woman smile at each other.

props.synopsis: Thai blockbuster family drama How to Make Millions Before Grandma Dies has left millions of film goers across South-East Asia in tears. Will it have the same effect on Australian audiences?

title.children: The Thai film that challenges you not to cry is coming to Australia

image.altText: cash lays on a kitchen table beside a cup of tea and a list of bills owing

props.synopsis: With cost of living issues still at large, two experts share their view on whether rigid budgeting is the right strategy to manage household cashflow.

title.children: Three budgeting methods to help manage your cash in a cost of living crisis

image.altText: A high-altitude balloon carrying solar panels floats in the sky.

props.synopsis: Balloons were used in all shapes and sizes throughout history for military purposes. Now they are making a comeback, with new tech capabilities floating in the stratosphere.

title.children: After an earlier era of flying 'sausages' and 'jellyfish', balloon warfare is having a renaissance

image.altText: Two older Indigenous women - Janina Harding and Destiny Deacon - standing together at an exhibition opening

props.synopsis: This year's NAIDOC theme is Keep the Fire Burning! Blak, Loud and Proud. Late artist Destiny Deacon lived that ethos.

title.children: Remembering Destiny Deacon: 'Warrior woman' and one of the world's best photographers

image.altText: Nicola Moriarty standing in front of a green Booktopia sign, hundreds of copies of Every Last Suspect in front of her

props.synopsis: Author Nicola Moriarty was only just at Booktopia's Sydney headquarters on May 30, signing hundreds of copies of her latest book Every Last Suspect. She's saddened the Australian book retailer has gone into voluntary administration.

title.children: Booktopia played an important role in supporting Australian authors, who are lamenting its collapse

image.altText: An illustration shows instant coffee, a plunger, a pour-over device and a stovetop coffee maker.

props.synopsis: Instant coffee could become even more expensive as Vietnamese producers fear farming land in the country could be halved by 2050 due to climate change.

title.children: Instant coffee prices set to increase as crops in Vietnam suffer yield loss

image.altText: Storm clouds gather over Cracknet Lookout on the new south wales Central Coast

props.synopsis: Three separate cloud bands sweeping across Australia during the coming week are likely to drop at least a few millimetres of rain on every patch of ground south of Brisbane to Geraldton.

title.children: Widespread soaking ahead for Australia as BOM now tips wet winter and spring

image.altText: Concept art showing interior of sports stadium with cricket match underway.

props.synopsis: New concept images of the planned stadium at Hobart's Macquarie Point have been released — with the Tasmanian government saying when completed, the multipurpose arena "will be the largest timber-roofed stadium in the world".

title.children: Hobart's new stadium to be 'largest timber-roofed' arena in the world, Tasmanian government says

image.altText: Masoud Pezeshkian raises his fist in the air in celebration.

props.synopsis: Reformist candidate Masoud Pezeshkian wins Iran's runoff presidential election, besting hardliner Saeed Jalili.

title.children: Masoud Pezeshkian wins Iran's presidential election

image.altText: Joe Biden

props.synopsis: In a campaign appearance in Wisconsin and in the first excerpt from a highly anticipated broadcast interview, US President Joe Biden appeared energetic and defiant in the face of mounting unease about his candidacy.

title.children: An episode or a condition? Joe Biden addresses his disastrous debate as his future hangs in the balance

image.altText: Caucasian woman with blonde hair

props.synopsis: Dr Bagus Mahadewa from the Ngoerah General Hospital where Rebecca Ode was treated said the Newcastle woman is able to speak but cannot remember what happened.

title.children: Indonesian police reveal details about how an Australian woman lost an eye in Bali

image.altText: A white double-storey house in South Melbourne.

props.synopsis: This once-resplendent South Melbourne cottage built by a well-to-do Scottish baker in the 1880s had slipped into ruin, with an alarming tilt to boot.

title.children: With rotted floors and overgrown vines, this Melbourne couple tackled what seemed like an impossible renovation

image.altText: Four uniformed detectives standing in the front yard of a property.

props.synopsis: Staff at a waste management facility in Epping discovered the body on Wednesday, with police linking the bin to a house in Coolaroo.

title.children: Homicide investigation launched after Melbourne rubbish tip staff find woman's body in bin

image.altText: Relatives mourn the death of stampede victims

props.synopsis: A deadly stampede in India earlier this week left 121 people dead and one of the main organisers has now surrendered to the police.

title.children: Organiser of Indian event where 121 were killed surrenders to police

image.altText: Jonas Abrahamsen smiles

props.synopsis: Obsessed with being as light as possible, Tour de France cyclist Jonas Abrahamsen went to extreme lengths to stay skinny. He's since put on 20kg of weight and is cycling better than ever.

title.children: 'It is quite sick': Tour de France rider's eating issue acts as warning for others

image.altText: Aerial view of Big Red Bash festival site.

props.synopsis: Many festivals are shutting down due to increasing costs, but despite fewer numbers this year organisers are confident this one will survive.

title.children: Like Burning Man but more remote, this is the desert festival Australians are spending big on
